examples.name: HP-12C Always Rounds N Up
examples.problem: Why does calculating N sometimes give a whole number when the exact answer should have decimals?
steps: When solving for N (number of periods), the HP-12C always rounds UP to the next highest integer
Example: If the exact answer is 9.006 years, HP-12C displays 10
Reason: In real-world scenarios, you need 10 complete periods to reach your goal, not 9.006 periods
examples.result: This matches real HP-12C calculators and differs from most other financial calculators and Excel

examples.name: g-12× / g-12÷ store n and i
examples.problem: Do g-12× and g-12÷ store into n/i on a real HP-12C?
steps: Yes. On the real HP-12C, `g-12×` (the blue function on the `n` key) multiplies the entered value by 12 and stores it into the `n` register in the same keypress.
Similarly, `g-12÷` (the blue function on the `i` key) divides the entered value by 12 and stores it into the `i` register in the same keypress.
Example (6% annual nominal → monthly): `6` `g-12÷` stores 0.5 in `i`.
examples.result: This simulator now matches that behavior: no extra unshifted press of `n`/`i` is required after `g-12×` / `g-12÷`.
